unit_learning_outcomes.description: Critically evaluate the diverse sources of data available about markets and customers and formulate appropriate approaches to analysis
Apply a range of frameworks and analysis methods creatively and critically to gain insights and make recommendations about markets and customers
Communicate recommendations and solutions to marketing problems effectively through data visualisation and narrative techniques

enrolment_rules.description: 40cp at 2000 level or above including MKTG2002 or MKTG202

assessments.description: This is a group task which contains an individual component. The individual component involves each student selecting appropriate customer behaviour data from a range of data sources and undertaking analyses to generate relevant output. Groups then synthesise individual student outputs using suitable frameworks to generate insights regarding customer behaviour and customer experiences. Utilising these insights, groups are required to communicate recommendations and solutions to customer-related marketing problems using data visualisation and narrative techniques. Length: Group Report: 2000 words; Individual student submission: 500 words

For this task, students will critically evaluate customer and market data and formulate appropriate approaches to data analysis. From this analysis, students will apply relevant frameworks and methods to generate insights and make recommendations regarding customer segments. Length: 8 - 10 slides (PowerPoint) /5-6 minute (Video)

For this task, students will analyse diverse sources of data from selected case studies and generate relevant output on how consumers value different product and service options. From these analyses, students will creatively and critically apply suitable frameworks and methods to generate insights and make relevant recommendations about consumer preferences. Length: 1500 words

data.description:
The digital revolution has created an enormous volume of data on markets, customers and the business environment which marketers have sought to incorporate into their strategic decision-making. Yet, raw data on its own adds very little to the strategic decision process. Marketers need to understand how to organise and analyse available data to generate actionable insights. Such insights are useful in anticipating future consumer needs, identifying trends, forecasting market conditions, gauging competition and making informed predictions about an ever-changing environment. Marketers then utilise these insights to build compelling narratives and to provide actionable recommendations for important marketing decisions.
In this unit students will investigate appropriate data, data sources and analytic techniques required to generate input for key marketing decisions regarding markets and customers. Students will assess suitable data analysis techniques and evaluate generated output to develop insights and determine potential marketing decision options. Additionally, students will appraise these key options by estimating likely impacts and integrating these impacts with practical organisational issues.
data.title: Marketing and Customer Insights
